content: Dow futures led premarket trading back into a narrow decline Tuesday, as the market generally hunkered down ahead of Apple's (AAPL) fiscal second-quarter results later in the day, a Fed interest-rate decision on Wednesday and the April payrolls report due Friday.Dow futures gave up brief gains and slipped less than 0.1% below fair value. Apple led the index while Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) posted its heaviest declines. Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures also dipped to a narrow losses. Akamai Technologies (AKAM) and Citrix Systems (CTXS) topped the Nasdaq 100. Seagate Technologies (STX) posted its heaviest loss.The three big benchmarks scored nominal gains for April — the Dow and S&P 500 each up 0.3%, and the Nasdaq struggling to a fractional gain. Still, the month was noteworthy in that it stopped a two-month slide that had sent the Nasdaq down 1.9% in February and 2.9% in March.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseMarkets continued to hold their breath on Tuesday, after President Trump delayed until June tariffs that were set to take effect on today against steel and aluminum imported from the European Union, Mexico and Canada. Agreements to avoid tariffs were in place with Australia, Brazil and Argentina, the White House said. In March, tariffs went into effect against China, Russia and Japan. Foreign steel stocks trading in the U.S. showed little reaction in premarket trading. Shares of U.S. Steel (X) dropped more than 1%. Steel stocks in general have been pulling back, consolidating since February.Another factor on investors radar: the Federal Open Market Committee begins its two-day meeting this morning in Washington, D.C. The meeting is expected to wrap up with a rate policy decision Wednesday afternoon. There will be no press conference following the announcement.In addition, several key pieces of economic news are expected today. Manufacturing purchasing mangers indexes for April are due from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and from the Institute For Supply Management at 10 a.m. ET. March construction spending numbers from the Commerce Department are expected at 10 a.m. ET.Automakers will be reporting April sales totals throughout the session.Apple, the most notable earnings report on the stock market today, added 0.6% in premarket trade. Analysts have raised concerns about the company's outlook, but Wall Street sees a 28% jump in earnings and a 15.5% revenue gain for the first quarter. That would mark the company's best results since the fourth quarter of 2015. Apple shares have declined for the past two months, and have been stalled below their 200-day moving average since late April.On the Dow, Pfizer dropped 1.3%, Merck tumbled 1.4%. Both drugmakers topped analyst's quarterly earnings expectations, but revenue growth stopped short of targets.HaynesBrands (HBI), NutriSystems (NTRI) and Allison Transmission (ALSN) were some other leading names in motion following earnings reports early Tuesday.Tenet Healthcare (THC) skipped up nearly 6% after delivering strong results after Monday's close. The premarket gain positioned the stock to narrowly clear a flat-base buy point at 25.24. Not all premarket moves carry over into regular trade.Seagate Technologies tumbled nearly 5% just after reporting fiscal third-quarter results. Earnings and revenue growth appeared to top expectations, and management raised the company's quarterly dividend to 63 cents.Under Armour (UAA) reversed an early gain and dropped 3% in premarket trading. The athletic wear maker's first-quarter sales and profit scored an easy beat, and the company reaffirmed full-year revenue expectations, guiding to general weakness in U.S. markets and a 25% sales surge overseas. Under Armour shares ended Monday 6% below an 18.85 buy point in a two-month-long base.Aerospace components maker TransDigm (TDG) popped 1.4% after reporting fiscal second-quarter results before the open. Results soared past analyst targets, and management gave full-year guidance a significant boost, citing TransDigm's two recent acquisitions. The stock closed Monday less than 2% above a handle buy point at 314.03.Among IBD 50 stocks, BofI Holding (BOFI) popped 5.6% in premarket action. At Monday's closing bell, BofI was not quite 6% below a flat base buy point at 42.69.Medical products maker Inogen (INGN) spiked 24% after clobbering analyst expectations in its first-quarter report late Monday. Stocks backed out of early mixed trade Thursday, with the Nasdaq following the Dow industrials and S&P 500 into moderate losses.A two-year federal budget deal moving toward a possible vote Thursday had generated early optimism among investors, as earnings reports from Tesla (TSLA), Twitter (TWTR) others were factors in the morning's trade.X The Nasdaq Composite popped 0.3% at the open, but quickly began trimming its gains. Viacom (VIAB) led the Nasdaq 100, up almost 11% after reporting its fiscal first-quarter results.The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.4% and the S&P 500 was down 0.2%. Verizon (VZ) and General Electric (GE) weighed on the Dow, down more than 1% each. HanesBrands (HBI) took the S&P 500's worst loss, falling more than 8% after its Q4 report.The morning's leading economic release showed first-time unemployment claims declining to 221,000 in the week ended Feb. 3, according to the Labor Department. That was down from 230,000 applications in the prior week, and was far below economist consensus estimates for an increase to 235,000 claims.Declining issues led risers by more than 2-to-1 on the Dow just after the open. Merck (MRK) took an early lead, up 0.8%.Apple (AAPL) inched up 0.1%, while the FANG stock tech leaders all lost ground. Shares continue to struggle to hold support at their 200-day moving average.Chip stocks were under pressure just after the open, after taking some steep losses on Wednesday. But Nvidia (NVDA) managed a 1% gain in early trade, moving the stock beyond buy range above a 218.77 buy point at the open.Tesla slipped 2.8% after reporting generally better-than-forecast fourth-quarter results after Wednesday's close.  Tesla is technically in a consolidation with a handle buy point of 360.60, but its relative strength line is lagging, and the stock has had trouble gaining any altitude above its 10-week moving average.Twitter spiked 20% after reporting fourth-quarter revenue and earnings growth above analysts' targets. The stock is extended after clearing a cup-with-handle base in December, and from a January rebound off 10-week support.Fast-moving IPO Canada Goose Holdings (GOOS) faltered 15% following its fiscal third-quarter report. The apparel maker's earnings and revenue easily surpassed analyst projections, and the company announced that Chief Financial Officer John Black would be replaced later this year by Jonathan Sinclair, the CFO for shoe retailer Jimmy Choo. The loss sent Canada Goose shares to a test of support at their 10-week moving average, but the stock remains extended from a November breakout.Most China-based stocks were quietly mixed, although online gaming leader NetEase (NTES) slumped 1.5% on a mixed fourth-quarter performance reported late Wednesday.The dollar bounced to its highest mark in two weeks, buoyed by optimism over a federal budget deal. Bonds reversed an early rebound, moving lower and lifting the 10-year yield by three basis points, to 2.87%.Oil prices – a leading factor in Wednesday's high-volume selling — reversed course and edged higher, shaking off some of the pressure from data showing production levels of more than 10 million barrels per day in the U.S., reported by the Energy Information Administration on Wednesday.Stocks in Europe fell hard in morning trade, but took back some ground after the Bank of England held interest rates steady, but hinted that an increase was in the works. The FTSE 100 in London dipped 0.9% and Frankfurt's DAX was down 1.2% in afternoon trade.Asia's stock markets were mostly positive, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 punching out a 1.1% advance. Apparel is back. You probably didn't think it went away, and in a literal sense it didn't. However, the 11-month port standoff on the West Coast was a problem for the Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing industry group.

"More than half of the clothes and shoes sold in the U.S. come through the West Coast ports," the American Apparel & Footwear Association noted May 22 in a news release after a union vote formally ended the standoff, adding, "Open and efficient ports are a priority for every single clothing and shoe company in the U.S."
A tentative pact was reached Feb. 20 before the May union vote.
Four stocks in the clothing manufacturing group carry an IBD Composite Rating of 92 or better.
G-III Apparel (GIII) has the most attractive base of the four stocks. G-III has sketched a flat base with a 60.26 buy point. The pattern is first stage.
G-III's earnings rose 19%, 28% and 21% in the past three years. Revenue grew 14%, 23% and again 23%. Sales to Macy's (which includes Bloomingdale's) account for 19% of net sales.
G-III reported fiscal Q1 results after Tuesday's close. G-III boosted earnings 400% on a 18% increase in sales, topping views on both. The stock rose after hours.
Hanesbrands (HBI) is in a flat base, too. However, the base is third stage and much of the base is under the 50-day line.

Carter's (CRI), a maker of baby and children's clothes, is extended from a first-stage breakout and 2% above a 101.80 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. An investor could wait for a second-stage base or enter on the three-weeks-tight.

While Michael Kors (KORS) has fallen from its perch as one of the hottest stocks in retail, Signet Jewelers (SIG) shines as "the most loved name" in specialty retail, according to a study by Sterne Agee that gauges investor sentiment. Hanesbrands (HBI), which is highly rated by IBD, comes in as a close second.
The top five stocks in Sterne Agee's sentiment index of specialty retailers tend to "meaningfully outperform" the bottom five over the next 12 months.

Sterne Agee's sentiment index — which includes 24 stocks — is based on price performance, short interest, analyst ratings, current P/E ratios relative to historic averages and a relative strength index.
The other three "high-sentiment" names among the top five: L Brands (LB), Gildan Activewear (GIL) and Burlington Stores (BURL) .

The bottom five, in descending order: Gap (GPS), Vera Bradley (VRA), Michael Kors, Fossil (FOSL) and Tuesday Morning (TUES). Kors, which traded as high as 101 in February 2014, was last trading around 64, about 34% off its high.

Signet's top ranking follows "solid Q4 results" and investors' increased comfort with the firm's big merger with Zale last year, noted Sterne Agee analyst Ike Boruchow. Signet stock has climbed sharply since mid-March and is trading at an all-time high, around 140.

Apparel company Hanesbrands is up more than 21% this year to around 34, 2% off its high from March 23. It holds a high 98 Composite Rating from IBD, out of a possible 99. Signet has a relatively strong 83 Composite Rating, as does L Brands, parent of Victoria's Secret.

Boruchow and his team estimate that Signet's capital strategy, including taking on low-interest debt and returning 70%-80% of annual free cash flow to shareholders via dividends and buybacks, could have a net benefit of 26 cents to EPS in 2016 and 82 cents in 2017. They see it "potentially growing to a $2-plus benefit by 2019."

Sterne Agee noted that lackluster retail traffic since late January began turning the corner in mid-March and was especially stronger in the final week of March, due in part to the earlier Easter than last year.
During March, discounting and promotions overall were more restrained than last year, including at Signet and L Brands, Boruchow noted.
Brands with meaningfully higher promotional activity noted in March were Michael Kors and Gap, namely Gap's namesake brand and Old Navy.

E-commerce shipping delays have weighed on Michael Kors since March 1, when heavy snow caused a roof to collapse at an Ohio fulfillment warehouse. Black Friday. Cyber Monday. Super Saturday. The annual retail running of the bulls is a treacherous terrain of sharpened elbows and trigger-happy mouse clicks for shoppers trying to get the best deal possible.The stakes are even higher for the stores themselves: The National Retail Federation has said that sales in November and December can account for anywhere from 20%-40% of a retailer's yearly sales. Perhaps fortunately for department stores like Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and others, there's nowhere to go but up this Christmas."Given the fact that last year was so horrible, the comps are easy," said Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar.As weather, inventory issues, heavy discounting and e-commerce giants like Amazon (AMZN) weighed, Macy's reported a 4.7% same-store sales decline in November and December of last year. Kohl's Q4 2015 comps edged up a mere 0.4%. Overall, last year's holiday retail sales disappointed with only 3% growth, said the NRF, less than expected.Holiday 2016 should prove to be a little less dire. The NRF predicts a 3.6% retail gain in November and December to $655.8 billion; online sales are seen rising 7%-10% to $117 billion. And retailers are feeling bullish. Target (TGT), Macy's and Nordstrom (JWN) all raised guidance going into the all-important shopping season.Predictably, online sales continue to eat into brick-and-mortar market share. Traditional stores are again gearing up to do battle with Amazon and friends.Wal-Mart (WMT) is pushing up its "Cyber Week" deals from Monday to Friday so that they start essentially the minute Thanksgiving Day is over. Target's "10 Days of Deals," which include both in-store and online promotions, already started on Saturday."If you look at the companies that reported earnings, it's e-commerce that's driving a significant amount of the growth," said Weishaar. "What's unique in it is mobile is becoming a higher penetration of the digital section, so that would be something new. I don't think a lot of the companies have figured out how to convert the sales on mobile."Shopping via smartphone is the next frontier. Thanksgiving Day and Christmas are projected to be the biggest mobile-shopping days of the year, said Adobe.One consequence of a ramp-up in retail digital wars, however, is that fewer people head into brick-and-mortar shops.Retail Metrics head Ken Perkins says the industry could see a "significant slowdown" in Black Friday foot traffic.Traffic fell in the mid-single to high-single-digits on Black Friday 2015, and retailers could see an equal or even greater decline this time around, he said, particularly as other shopping events during the year dilute the impact of the post-Thanksgiving sales day.Besides Cyber Monday and Super Saturday, the menu of existing shopping holidays has grown to include Amazon's Prime Day and even China-based Singles Day, among others.Foursquare's data are a little more optimistic; the company predicts a 3.5% year-over-year slide in Black Friday foot traffic, which would be "far less severe" than the prior year's figures."The importance of Black Friday from a traffic (perspective) to brick-and-mortar stores is going to continue to decelerate," said Weishaar. "With more people shopping online, the one specific day becomes less important."IBD'S TAKE: Adobe data indicate that Black Friday sales will be the "biggest ever," growing 11.3% from last year to $3.05 billion in sales. For a look at what else is happening this week, check out IBD's Investing Action Plan. Broadly speaking, inventory levels are cleaner in Q4, which translates to more targeted, strategic discounting instead of promotional wars, said Weishaar. But even in the absence of "everything must go"-type sales, that doesn't mean that consumers shouldn't expect to see a whole lot of deals floating around.Which retail names will be winners this year?Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel pointed out in a recent note that execs at various retailers have alluded to a challenging, promotional holiday season. Apparel company Hanesbrands has found its comfort zone. The maker of underwear, socks and T-shirts benefits from a string of intersecting trends: consistent demand for undergarments and other everyday apparel, a shift toward activewear clothing, strong brand recognition, its own low-cost production platform and a series of strategic acquisitions that have helped it bolster sales, analysts say.

"There's a lot to like here," Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar told IBD.After Hanesbrands (HBI) reported in April that its first-quarter adjusted earnings per share rose 16% from a year earlier to 22 cents on net sales that climbed 14% to $1.21 billion, the Winston-Salem, N.C.-based outfit raised its guidance for the full year. It forecast net sales of $5.9 billion to $5.95 billion for 2015, up from previous guidance of $5.78 billion to $5.83 billion, and adjusted EPS of $1.61 to $1.66, up from $1.58 to $1.63.2015 Gains In SightThe guidance represents an increase over 2014 results of 10.9% to 11.8% for net sales and 13% to 17% for adjusted EPS.The company, which sells its products wholesale to department stores and mass retailers, is cash-rich and expects to remain so, forecasting net cash from operating activities to total between $550 million and $600 million this year.Hanesbrands' stock is up 24% so far in 2015.Its strong financial performance and stock price appreciation help it earn an IBD Composite Rating of 95, meaning it outperforms 95% of stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors.The company belongs to IBD's Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing group. Hanes ranks third in the group by Composite Rating, behind G-III (GIII) and Carter's (CRI).The group's largest name by market cap is VF Corp.VFC, which owns 7 For All Mankind, Lee and Wrangler jeans among its brands, which also include activewear names Lucy and The North Face.Second in the group by size isUnder Armour (UA), a big beneficiary of the activewear trend, along with Nike (NKE), in the Apparel-Shoes & Related Manufacturing group.Knights Apparel For SchoolsHanesbrands' elevated outlook reflected a solid start to 2015 and the anticipated impact from its latest acquisition, it said. Early in the second quarter Hanesbrands closed its buy of Knights Apparel, which sells clothes such as t-shirts and sweatshirts with licensed college logos.The deal amplified two key trends for Hanesbrands: ongoing growth in activewear and related clothing, and expansion via acquisitions.Hanesbrands' product lines include Hanes and Playtex. The Knights Apparel acquisition complements its Gear for Sports operation, as well as its prominent Champion brand."They are riding the athletic apparel cycle for sure," John Kernan, an analyst at Cowen & Co., told IBD.Analysts say that popular fashion has in recent years moved away from the likes of skinny jeans and toward activewear and sports-themed clothing, including workout pants, bolstering Hanesbrands' fortunes. On top of this, as consumers discard former fashion preferences for newer ones, they often also buy new undergarments that mesh with their newer designs, analysts say, and this too benefits Hanesbrands' core Hanes innerwear business.Acquiring The GoodsThe company in 2013 bought Maidenform Brands, a seller of bras and other undergarments for women, and in 2014 bought DBApparel, a marketer of intimate apparel and hosiery in Europe.Those two deals bolstered sales last year and Hanesbrands' bottom line, with fourth-quarter profit more than doubling.Morningstar's Weishaar said Hanesbrands produces most of its merchandise in-house and uses its massive scale to keep costs relatively low. When it looks at acquisitions, it typically eyes targets that outsource at least some of their production work. After closing a deal, it then brings the acquired company onto its own manufacturing platform, lowering expenses and boosting profits, she said."So I think that the M&A play just continues on for them," Weishaar said. "I think that's going to be one of their biggest growth drivers."Cowen's Kernan agreed. "They are going to make more acquisitions for sure," he said."They do a really good job rolling up companies and putting them on their platform."In a report, Kernan estimated that Hanesbrands could reach a run rate of $700 million in annual free cash flow next year, bolstering its ability to pursue more deals."With only 6% of sales in Europe, we see opportunity for HBI to acquire brands in a fragmented market," he wrote in the report.Kernan projected that Hanesbrands could complete an additional $1.7 billion in deals over about five years. That, he noted, would leave the company generating double-digit earnings growth for years even if expansion in its core innerwear business were modest.But the core business, Kernan added, is on solid ground. The company's brands, he wrote, are "enduring and powerful."Within the $20 billion U.S. innerwear market, Kernan estimates that Hanes holds an 18% share at retail.Weishaar noted that innerwear is still Hanesbrands' biggest business. That, she added, is a good thing because it infuses reliability.She said most of the innerwear business consists of "very basic" undergarments. People tend to know their size and what brand works for them. Most don't want to try on undergarments at stores, so tend to go with a familiar brand. Hanesbrands is familiar to a big share of them. "They just want to pick it up and go," she said.New Socks And UnderwearUnlike other lines of clothing, consumers need to regularly replace their supplies of apparel such as underwear, t-shirts and socks."It's a replenishment business, so demand is steady," Weishaar said. "It's a really great space to be in."Hanesbrands declined IBD's interview request, citing a customary quiet period ahead of reporting second-quarter earnings.While speaking at a May conference, CEO Richard Noll acknowledged that Hanesbrands' business may fluctuate quarter to quarter "as retailers can adjust their inventory levels up and down." But over the course of a typical full year, "our business is remarkably stable due to the replenishment nature of most of our categories."That, along with boosts from acquisitions, makes him confident in Hanesbrands' long-term growth."I feel really good about our ability to drive EPS up double digits for many years to come," he said.

When it comes to feeding the consumer appetite for bargains, China's Vipshop Holdings follows a tried and true recipe that's helped nurture a healthy growth spurt.

Vipshop (VIPS), which started in 2008 and went public in March 2012, is somewhat of a rare breed among retail websites. It sells quality branded apparel, accessories, home goods and other lifestyle products at a 30% to 70% discount to the original retail price using a "flash sales" model. Every morning at 10 Beijing time, it launches new flash sales on a finite quantity of products or services online for a limited time.

To provide shoppers with a greater opportunity to buy featured discounted products, each customer is limited to purchasing two pieces of the same item and each shopping cart can hold only 20 items at one time, except for food products.

As with other popular flash-sale sites, which sell everything from high fashion to hotel rooms, the idea is to create an impulse-driven shopping experience while helping to move excess inventory sourced from a variety of vendors.
As of the end of 2012, Vipshop had an impressive lineup of goods with exclusive rights to sell selective products from more than 700 brands.
Preferred Products

Vipshop features products from more than 5,800 brands, including international labels such as such as Nike (NKE), Disney (DIS), Hanesbrands (HBI) and Lee (owned by VF Corp. (VFC); and domestic brands like Hstyle. Its top three selling brands are Adidas, Nike and Kappa, a domestic sporting goods brand.
Vipshop's approach has played well with customers. In 2012, sales more than tripled to $692 million. It ended that year with close to 27 million registered users.
It has also scored a big hit with investors. Vipshop's stock price has rocketed nearly 450% over the past 12 months to around 100.

Vipshop has been profitable the past five quarters. It earned 26 cents per American Depositary Share (ADS) in the most recent third quarter, up from one cent a year earlier. Sales rocketed 146% to $383.7 million as it saw a 132% rise in active customers to 4 million and a 116% rise in total orders to 11.7 million.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year 2013 earnings to reach $1.04 per ADS, up from a 4-cent loss in 2012. They see a 107% surge in 2014 and a 59% rise in 2015.

China-based UBS analyst Erica Poon Werkun forecast a 62% revenue compound annual growth rate from 2012 to 2017, driven mainly by growth on active customers, in her January initiation note on Vipshop, which she rates a buy.
Why the bright prospects?
"We believe VIPS addresses issues on the supply side, namely excess inventories in distribution channels and the difficulty in penetrating lower-tier cities," noted Werkun.
It also addresses the consumer's demand for "superior product value proposition, newness and convenience in shopping," she added.
Vipshop's main growth drivers are its discounts and product selection, adds Kelland Willis, an associate analyst at Forrester Research.
She says Vipshop offers access to brands at affordable prices that for the most part aren't available on other websites in China.

"Vipshop has hit that niche in China's mass market with mid-range name brands like Adidas and Puma that are considered luxury products among this consumer group in China," she said. "They've really done a great job catering to middle-income consumers age 18 to 35 by offering them name-brand products that they wouldn't otherwise be able to afford. The consumers they target are brand-conscious and are excited to be able to shop for those products at price points they can afford."
Three Growth Drivers
In an initiation report, China-based HSBC analyst Chi Tsang cites three growth drivers for Vipshop. No. 1 is the fact that "the market is large and growing rapidly."

Tsang estimates the market for discount retail in China is $40 billion, growing at over 50% a year, and Vipshop has a 4% market share. The company's other growth drivers are "limited competition" from traditional discount retailers and "substantial potential upside to customer numbers."

Among Vipshop's strengths is its mix of international and domestic brands in its flash sales, says Willis. She says not many websites in China offer the mix of both. And the sites that do offer that mix, she says, don't do as good a job presenting the brands as Vipshop does. Vipshop does a "good job highlighting" whether a brand is international or domestic in its flash sales, "whereas other multibrand retailers tend to sell products by category and you don't know the actual brand name," she added.
Competitive Environment

Still, overall industry rivalry in China is "intense," says Tsang, and Vipshop competes with both dedicated flash-sale players and online marketplaces. Its primary rivals include business-to-consumer e-commerce firms that sell similar products and services online, such as Tmall, 360Buy and Dangdang (DANG), and other online flash sales firms, says a company filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Marketplaces "dominate" the e-commerce scene in China, writes Willis in her China online retail forecast report for 2013 to 2018.

The biggest marketplaces in the country include Taobao, Tmall, Suning and Jingdong as well as Amazon.com (AMZN). But Vipshop has some advantages over rivals, says Tsang. They include "customer loyalty, driven by a high-quality product selection chosen by what is considered to be the largest team of buyers in China and a dedicated customer service organization; and effective operational management and financial controls."

Meanwhile, online shopping in China is growing faster than most anyone originally expected, Willis noted in her report. In 2013, China's online retail market — which includes business-to-consumer and consumer-to-consumer sites — surpassed $300 billion, Willis says.

Stock futures pointed sharply higher, but were off their early highs ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, following some mixed early economic news and as markets rallied in Europe.

Dow futures steered up 118.7 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures traded 25.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.1-point gain. Small caps were positive and steady, with Russell 2000 futures holding a 4-point gain.

The stock market today opens with a two-day rally under its belt, with both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending higher in their trading ranges on Tuesday. Both indexes remain below their 50-day moving averages, although the Nasdaq is positioned for a possible test of that line this week.

Personal spending rose 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, a welcome improvement from October's zero-gain showing and in line with economist expectations. Personal incomes rose 0.3%, a tad below October's 0.4% gain but better than views for a 0.2% advance.

Durable goods orders were flat for the month, sharply below October's (downwardly revised) 2.9% gain, but better than the 0.5% contraction projected by economist consensus. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.
At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.
The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.

Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.

Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.

In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.

Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).

Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.

5:15 p.m. Update: Indexes slunk to deep lows, with banks and insurers leading the descent. Transportation stocks also took broad hits as fears of a failed U.S. auto industry unraveled across the supply chain.
The NYSE composite tunneled 6.7%, the Nasdaq composite shoveled a 6.5% loss and the S&P 500 caved 6.1%. All three indexes undercut Oct. 28 lows, erasing the market's gains back to April '03.
The Dow limped home with a 5.1% decline, leaving it just above its Oct. 10 low, but at its first sub-8,000 close in more than five years.
The NYSE's financial index knocked out a 10.8% loss. The Dow transports dumped 8.1%, diving to a four-year closing low.
Volume evaporated across the afternoon, with preliminary data showing action turning narrowly mixed before the close.

The upside list narrowed through the afternoon. None of the Dow's 30 components advanced. One Nasdaq 100 issue, enterprise software maker CA (CA), added three pennies. Eight companies on the S&P 500 posted gains.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stock Market's Losses Deepen, Mark Fresh Lows
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and NYSE composite undercut their Nov. 13 lows as the market's losses mounted.
At the closing bell, the Nasdaq had plummeted 6.5%, the NYSE 6.6%, the S&P 500 6.1% and the Dow 5.1%. All closed at session lows.
Volume rose on the Big Board but eased slightly on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary figures.
The sharpest declines came in the final hour. That continued a trend this week in which the market made decisive moves late in the day.
Practically every industry group fell, led by transportation, home building, steel and financials.
More details will be available in the 5:15 p.m. market update.
3:15 p.m. Update: NYSE, Nasdaq Undercut Recent Lows
Stocks slid deeper as trading entered the final hour.

The NYSE composite joined the Nasdaq, undercutting its Oct. 28 low with a 3.8% loss. The Nasdaq composite and the S&P 500 showed 3.3% declines. The Dow eased off its low, but remained 2.2% in the red.
Banks were three of the Dow's top five decliners. Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) was the only Dow component to log a gain.
Yahoo (YHOO) was a drag on the Nasdaq 100. Midcaps showed some of the heaviest losses, with the S&P 400 off 4.8%.
Volume on the NYSE remained higher, but trading eased on the Nasdaq to just 1% above Tuesday's level.
The release of minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Oct. 28-29 meeting show Fed officials expect continued economic contraction through the first half of next year.
The minutes also showed the Fed committed to additional rate cuts and in agreement "that it would take whatever steps were necessary to support the recovery of the economy."
Auto parts retailer AutoZone (AZO) dove 11% to near the two-year low notched on Oct. 10. Shares have been correcting since September.
All but one of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD lost ground. The holdout was food and meat products.
2:15 p.m. Update Nasdaq Hits New Low, Volume Stays High
BY PATRICK CAIN
The Nasdaq undercut its Nov. 13 low as other indexes continued to struggle in midafternoon trading.
The tech-heavy index fell 3.8%, hitting levels not seen since April 2003. The NYSE composite was off 4%, the S&P 500 3.4% and the Dow 2.3%.
Volume remained high.

AstraZeneca (AZN), a drug maker, dove 10.3% in huge volume. U.S. regulators cleared the way for rival Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) to make a generic form of AstraZeneca's Pulmicort Respules, a child asthma medication. AstraZeneca announced it too will unveil a generic form of the drug.

First Solar (FSLR), the Arizona solar firm, fell 7.5%. The company, which was once the leading solar stock, is  along with the industry  getting slammed by lower oil prices. First Solar is down about 44% from its November high.
Kirby Corporation (KEX) hit a more-than-three-year low after it dived 9.9%. The shipper is in the Transportation-Ship group, which was ranked 166 of 197 groups in Wednesday's IBD.
1:15 p.m. Update: Volume Gathers As Indexes Hold Near LowsIndexes eased off lows but remained deep in the red in early afternoon trading.
The NYSE composite tripped to a 3.5% loss; the Nasdaq composite faltered 3.3%. The S&P 500 dropped 2.9%, and the Dow held to a 2% decline.
Selling in small caps picked up, pressing the S&P 600 to a 4.4% drop. The Dow transports skidded 5%. The NYSE's financial index tumbled 6.9%.
General Motors (GM) and Citigroup (C) continued to post the Dow's heaviest price losses.
Volume gathered momentum, up 13% on the NYSE and 7% on the Nasdaq compared with this time Tuesday.

Nordic American Tanker Shipping (NAT) gapped down to lose 4%, putting a crimp in the right side of a three-month base. The stock is about the only one in its industry group that's come off lows to attempt forming a base.
NuVasive (NUVA), a developer of treatments for spine disorders, toppled 14%, sinking further from its 10- and 40-week moving averages.
12:15 p.m. Update: Sellers Pounce; Trade Picks Up
BY VINCENT MAO
The major stock indexes hit new intraday lows in late-morning trading Wednesday. Worries about the economy and the fate of automakers have pressured equities from the opening bell.
The NYSE composite slid 3.7% and neared its Nov. 13 low. The Dow stumbled 2.5%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were down 3.2% each.
Volume was tracking higher across the board.

Best Buy (BBY) tumbled 14% to its lowest level in more than five years. S&P downgraded the electronic giant's credit rating, saying that it would be more challenged by the weak economic environment than previously thought.

Baidu.com (BIDU) slumped for a fourth straight session, down 10% to a new 52-week low. The Chinese Web search firm has tumbled more than 30% this week. China Central Television has accused it of letting unlicensed medical companies pay for higher rankings in its search results.
Google  (GOOG) fell 3%, sliding further south of the 300 level.
11:15 a.m. Update: Financials Draw Indexes Deeper In Mixed TradingIndexes tried twice to pierce through to higher ground in morning trade, but were hauled back into the red by stumbling financials.

The NYSE composite slumped 2.2%, dogged by a 4.1% loss in its financial Index  more than double any other NYSE sector. The S&P 500 dropped 1.5%. The Nasdaq composite and the Dow sank 1.2% and 1%. Midcaps took a harder hit than most, with the S&P 400 off 2.6%.
JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) tracked just behind General Motors (GM) as the top decliners on the Dow. Hartford Financial Services (HIG) was the S&P 500's leading anchor.
Volume remained mixed, slightly higher on the NYSE and off by about an equal amount on the Nasdaq.
Several stocks still pressed on to gains.
Cephalon (CEPH) jumped 2% in heavy trading. The move punched the branded prescription drug maker above a 77.05 buy point on an eight week cup-with-handle base.

California Water Services (CWT) popped to a 3% gain. The water source owner and distributor has advanced in three of four recent sessions. Shares were 4% above the 39.57 buy point in a nine-week, cup-with-handle base.

Overseas, markets in Asia closed generally lower, although China's Shanghai composite blasted to a 6.1% gain. China Petroleum & Chemical, aka Sinopec (SNP), the country's largest refiner, pegged the 10% daily trading limit as investors banked on plans for fuel supply reforms.
Markets in Europe and the U.K. were showing strong losses in afternoon trade, dragged lower by banks and commodities.
10:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Down On Mixed Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks were mostly lower in volatile trading early Wednesday after a rebound attempt faltered.
At 9:56 a.m. EST, the NYSE composite was down 1.3%, the S&P 500 0.9%, the Dow 0.7% and the Nasdaq 0.6%.
Volume was tracking mixed, with NYSE higher and Nasdaq lower.

BJ's Wholesale (BJ) gapped up and gained 6% after it beat views and gave a bright outlook. Before the open, the retailer reported Q3 earnings of 48 cents a share, up 37% from the prior year and 2 cents above views. BJ's raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $2.20 to $2.30 a share from prior guidance of $2.10 to $2.20. Analysts expected $2.21.
Group mate Costco  (COST) edged up 1%.

Financials were mostly lower. Citigroup (C) dropped 6% on news that it plans to buy remaining assets from structured investment vehicles at an estimated value of $17.4 billion, down from $21.5 billion in September.
Morgan Stanley (MS) also lost 6%. The head of its Asian prime brokerage arm is leaving the firm.
Crude oil bounced back from a 22-month low. The December contract rose 80 cents to $55.19 a barrel.
9:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Headed For Red Open
BY VINCENT MAO
Stock futures pointed to a lower open Wednesday, ahead of more testimony from the heads of the Big Three automakers.
Nasdaq futures fell 12 points vs. value fair, S&P 500 futures dropped 13 points and Dow futures gave up 113 points.

Executives from Ford  (F), General Motors (GM) and Chrysler LLC will again plead with Congress for a $25 billion bailout in order to stave off bankruptcy and get back on track. The execs warned that their collapse would not just hurt the auto industry, but would ripple through an already weak economy. Ford and General Motors shares fell 2% and 4%, respectively, in the pre-market.

Toyota Motor (TM) will reportedly halt production at U.S. and Canadian plants for two extra days in December. The Japanese automaker also will cut about 250 temporary workers at its Georgetown, Ky. facility.

In a sign of a weakening economy, consumer prices fell by a record 1% in October vs. an expected decline of 0.8%. Core prices, which exclude food and energy, slipped 0.1% vs. expectations for a 0.1% rise.
October housing starts dropped by 4.5% to 791,000 units, though that was still above forecasts of 780,000 units.
The minutes from the Oct. 29 Fed meeting will be released at 2 p.m. EST.

Every week, I usually either outline a unique way to screen for stocks or go over a proven, profitable trading strategy.

But this week, I'm starting at square one and going over why screening is so crucial. Even more importantly, though, I'll cover why backtesting is the most important step of all. Why Should I Use a Stock Screener?
The short answer is:
"Because there are over 10,000 stocks out there and you need a way to find the good ones".
The longer answer is:
Other than buying the stocks that are talked about in the media or recommended by friends, how else are you going to find stocks that meet certain fundamental characteristics?

Even if you don't use a screener now, most people do their own 'screening' one way or another. They may hear that a stock has a certain Growth Rate, or a certain P/E Ratio or Sales Surprise, for example. They then find themselves listening for or reading about stocks that meet this criteria.
Well if you want to find stocks that meet certain criteria, you can find them quickly and easily with a stock screener.
But, just because you narrow 10,000 stocks down to a handful, doesn't necessarily mean that you've picked the best ones.
You might have picked the worst ones.
But how will you know? Backtesting!
Once you've created a screen, you can then backtest it and see how your screening strategy has performed.
In other words, does your screen generally find stocks that go up once they've been identified? Or does your screen generally find stocks that get buried once they've been identified?
This is good stuff to know.
With backtesting, you can see how successful your stock-picking strategy has performed in the past, so you'll have a better idea as to what your probability of success will be in the future.
Of course, past performance is no guarantee of future results, but what else do you have to go by?
Keep in mind, a screening and backtesting program isn't a 'box of magic'.
But it is a great way to see what works and what doesn't BEFORE you put your money at risk!

But remember, a great strategy for picking winning stocks doesn't exclude you from ever having another loser. On the contrary, even some of the best strategies 'only' have win ratios of 70% or 80%. (NOT 100%.)
If your strategy picks winners far more often than losers, though, you can feel confident that your next pick will have a high probability of success.

And don't be the guy who 'accidentally' gets into one or two good stocks and thinks he's the next Warren Buffett. If your stock account is important to you, test your stock-picking strategies to see if your method for finding winners is a repeatable one.
And that's why someone should use a Screener and a Backtester.
